utterances: Hello.
Pam, go ahead.
Hello there.
Hi.
I am actually Dustin and Derrick Nippert's aunt.
Whoa.
You're going to throw your stress ball at your brother now?
I think you're supposed squeeze it.
He had to take vacation days to cover - not been able to get to work.
And I just want to thank the Diamondback organization for giving those two guys this great opportunity.
You have no idea how proud our entire family is of those two.
I mean, when Dustin had his opening in the big league, in Pittsburgh, we cleared out the town of the Bellville(ph), Ohio on school buses to come and cheer for the Diamondbacks.
So it is just awesome.
Rick Parr would not object if you bused the whole town down to Tucson and took them to…
I wish - hey, we could do that, you had better believe we would be there.
Well, listen.
I'm part of the Dustin.
I just think he's a great player and I think that he is destined for the major leagues, he's the next one, in my opinion, to go.
We are going to be extremely happy for him because he is a major league player.
And it's just a matter of time.
Growing up, I mean, through his high school years, I mean, he had so many, like, physical difficulties that, I mean, this is just so unbelievable.
And coming from the little tiny farming community that we're all from, it's just remarkable.
We are just so proud of he and Derrick both.
It's just - they're just both unbelievable guys.
We love them to death.
Pam, we wish you and them the best of luck.
Thank you so much.
So long.
Well, Neal, let me say this about Dustin.

The reason that I think he is going to make - there's couple of reasons, but one of them is that when he pitched in our championship bid, I mean we - we won the Pacific Coast League Championship and then as the Tucson Sidewinders in 2006, we won the Triple-A Championship.
But when Dustin pitched last year, he was pivotal in some pivotal games, and that - and so Dustin under pressure can pitch.
And that's what they want to see.
They want to see you pitch in a play-off game.
They want to see you pitch when the odds are against you.
And that's part of this building process too because, see, that tells you the character of the ballplayer.
I happen to like Dustin a lot.
I think he's going to be a major league player for a number of years.
When he finally gets there, and when he sticks, he's going to please a lot of people for a good number of years.

The only thing that I hope is that Dustin never forgets his roots and if we need some autographed baseballs to promote things, I just hope that he goes, you know what, I'll be glad to sign a couple of dozen for you to help the next guy make it.
Let's talk with Patrick.
Patrick with us from Louisville in Kentucky.
Hi.

When I was kid, I had some friends in the neighborhood whose dad was a triple-A umpire and I thought that was even a notch above the players in terms of commitment, long odds against making it, and, you know, you talked about how the players are on the road half the time, but the umpires are always on the road and the crowd is always hostile and…
Yeah, that's true.
They are always wearing a black hat.
That's right, yeah.
Well, think of it this way, the umpires now, we do an eight-game series.
They only do a four-game.
They won't let them do an eight game.
So they travel twice as much as the players travel.
So you got to keep that in mind.
Yeah, there's some dedication level, but again, the payoff when you make it to the show is huge.
And so, you know that dedication and sacrifice will payoff.
Thanks for the call, Patrick.
Okay.
Bye.
We're talking about Minor League Baseball with Rick Parr of the Tucson Sidewinders.
You're listening to the TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And that call raises a question.
Everybody in the Minor Leagues is in a way looking for a promotion.
The groundskeepers, the trainers, the play-by-play announcers as well as the players, and I suppose, even general managers would like to be working in Major League Baseball.
I think, you know, Neal, I wouldn't disagree with that.
I think that everybody is always looking for the next step.
And, you know, and the division between Minor League and Major League is so vast as far as the pay off that, you know, it's just incredible.
And if you feel that you are that talented -and you're right - if you're a Major League groundskeeper, you're somebody.
You really are.
You have made it to the pinnacle of your field.
A little bit different for general managers.
For me, I don't aspire the Major League - to be a general manager on the Major League level.
Mine is more quality of life.

I have always felt that a community like Tucson deserves a quality of life and if you can play triple-A baseball in a community like Tucson, then you have done great things for parents around the world because they want to bring up their kids in a great environment.

And there's no better environment in the world to take your kid to the game and spend two and a half, three hours with them eating hotdogs and talking about the day and how they're going to do, you know, different things in school and stuff like that.
And I tell you, it's wonderful.
I've got two kids, they come out to the ballpark all the time.
And it's part of the quality of life that I want my kids to grow up in.
Here's an email we got from Robert in Susquehanna, Pennsylvania.
My dad loves to tell the story of a co-worker who was a talented player at college and part of the Pittsburgh Pirates farm system.

At about the age of 23, an 18-year-old kid walked into the training camp and was so much better than my dad's friend that he knew he would or could ever be that he left the dream of making the show behind.
The name of that kid was Roberto Clemente, and I'm sure you heard variations on that story a hundred times.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Let's see if we can get another caller on the line.
This is Stew.
Stew with us from Indianapolis.
Hello?
Hi.
You're on the air, Stew, go ahead please.
Vanessa Daley with TAPS listens as children share what they've learned at this camp.
Even somebody died in your family, you can still have fun.
You can share your feelings that you never shared with people.
Yes, Neal, hi.
First of all, I want to, kind of, confirm something Rick said earlier.

I've got sports counselors that's worked with (unintelligible) players, and I've got kids who are the bonus babies who, kind of, feel like should be handed to him on a silver plate and really not willing to do the disciplined work and meet the challenges that they need to, to really climb up the ladder.
I have other kids who were surprised when they were drafted and want it so bad that they're open to doing whatever it takes to go ahead and try to progress.
But the thing where I think baseball might be missing the boat is that these kids are living away from home for the first time in an unprotected environment.
They either get signed out of high school or else they go to college.
And a lot of them don't have the life skills to really adapt to the pressure and challenges they're facing.
A lot of them don't know how to mentally handle challenges because as you pointed out, a lot of them start easy to them then suddenly they're playing guys with the same talent level.
And I really think baseball was - and I've actually suggested this to a couple of people on the Major League level through by contact to (unintelligible).

But (unintelligible), he used to play with the Royals that they really need to attend to the whole person a little better to protect their investments because these kids need these life skills to deal with these pressures.
What do you think, Rick Parr?
Well, I think, there's a lot of truth to that.
And let's take a look at just this schedule and the rigorous schedule that they have.
They've never done anything like this in high school.
And even when you play, let's just take a college kid that plays.
His schedule is nowhere close to what they play in the Minor Leagues or the Major Leagues.

And so what they have to learn is, they're going to work every day and they're going to have to travel half of those days that they do work and then they're going to play games at night and they're going to get out of there about 11:00 or 12:00 midnight and they're going to get back up and they're going to do this all over again.
And here's an existential question, how many times can you watch the same sports center?

Oh, I'm telling you, it is a brutal schedule and the guys that know and can adjust the fastest to it and make it more of a normal schedule for themselves are the ones that really start to rise to the top quickly.
And I got to tell you that…
Quickly.
Like if you're not a bonus baby or not, it's part of the way that the systems works.
Rick Parr, thanks very much for your time today.
Thank you.
